item.description:
Pencils, notebooks ‚Äî¬†and Narcan?

Concerned parents of incoming college freshmen are adding the life-saving nasal spray to back-to-school lists this year ‚Äî along with condoms, Plan B and more modern must-haves that might have been unthinkable a generation ago.

And that‚Äôs just fine with students like Summer, 20, who said they prefer a matter-of-fact approach to the way campus life is lived now.

‚ÄúI administered Narcan to a girl who was passed out on the front lawn of an off-campus frat party,‚Äù the psych major from North Carolina, who didn‚Äôt want to use her last name, told The Post. ‚ÄúIt literally saves lives.‚Äù¬†

Narcan, officially known as Naloxone, is an opioid antagonist that reverses the effects of illicit substances, such as fentanyl.¬†

It‚Äôs a serious topic of discussion among older folks with chickadees poised to leave the nest.

From Facebook mom groups to viral TikTok clips, ‚Äúcollege survival kits‚Äù with the miracle medication are all the rage ‚Äî along with contraception pills and other grown-up adds.

Idaho mom Jamie, 42, and daughter Sophia Green, 18, recently made a big splash with a social media reveal of their list of nontraditional necessities for Sophia‚Äôs first day of classes at Boise State University this fall.

And while the 5.6 million viewers of their clip were largely supportive, digital detractors downed the trend, arguing that plying adolescents with the preventative products is ‚Äúsad‚Äù and ‚Äúembarrassing.‚Äù¬†

One contrarian commenter even wrote, ‚ÄúDamn, teach your daughters common sense, resilience and willpower.‚Äù

Protesters of the ultra-progressive shift may rush to shame so-called ‚Äúhelicopter parents‚Äù for inadvertently giving teens the green light to experiment.

But Yamalis Diaz, an adolescent psychologist at NYU Langone Health, said cautious adults are neither overstepping boundaries with their kids ‚Äî¬†nor granting them permission to party.¬†

Instead, they‚Äôre simply preparing the pups for real-world eventualities.¬†

‚ÄúMillennials and Gen Xers, who grew up in a very flexible, open-minded time, are now sending their Gen Z children off to college fully equipped to handle difficult situations,‚Äù Diaz told The Post.¬†

‚ÄúIf parents choose to get Narcan or condoms for their kids, the message isn‚Äôt, ‚ÄòHere, go do drugs and have sex,‚Äô ‚Äù she insisted. ‚ÄúThe message is, ‚ÄòI don‚Äôt want you to get into any kind of tricky predicaments, but here are some tools that you can use to make smart choices after the fact.‚Äô ‚Äù

It‚Äôs a message that youngsters need now more than ever, statistics show.¬†

An alarming 50,000 teenagers confessed to misusing fentanyl, a synthetic opioid, in 2023, per a recent report from the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, a branch of the Department of Health and Human Services.

Researchers discovered a 47% spike in teen fentanyl use from 2022 to 2023. They attributed the startling uptick to the fact that many youngsters could have taken it without realizing.

Representatives for the Drug Enforcement Administration have deemed fentanyl, a Schedule I drug, the ‚Äúleading cause of death for adults ages 18 to 45 in the US,‚Äù according to the DEA‚Äôs Campus Drug Prevention site.

Summer‚Äôs distressed schoolmate could have ended up just another statistic ‚Äî but luckily, the quick thinker had taken an on-campus harm reduction seminar and knew what to do.

‚ÄúShe was super pale, her breathing was shallow and her pupils were pinpoint, which is a sign of overdose,‚Äù she recalled.¬†

Now, she‚Äôs always prepared with a supply of the medication, which is available as an over-the-counter commodity at most nationwide drugstores and online outlets like Amazon, where it costs around $45.¬†

‚ÄúI always keep Narcan in my purse when I go to college events, parties and festivals ‚Äî because you just never know,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúBetter to be safe than sorry.‚Äù¬†

Maine mama Gretchen Schaefer, 50, who‚Äôs sending her daughter, Ingrid, 19, back to school with a stash of Narcan and Plan B, agrees.¬†

In fact, the mother of two said she‚Äôs encouraging others with college kiddos to follow suit.¬†

‚ÄúThe most common objection I hear is, ‚ÄòWell, my kid doesn‚Äôt hang out with drug users,‚Äô ‚Äù said Schaefer, noting that Ingrid kicks it with the sober crowd at her school in Massachusetts. ‚ÄúBut what if someone was slipped something and they have to reverse an overdose?‚Äù¬†

The vigilant mom is also keen on reversing the effects of unprotected sex.

‚ÄúIn the case of sexual assault, I want her or someone on her dorm floor to have the Plan B on hand,‚Äù she added. ‚ÄúIt was $6 at Costco.‚Äù

To ensure that Ingrid knows how and when to use all of the remedies in her ‚Äúhealth kit,‚Äù Schaefer‚Äôs even created, printed and laminated an emoji-coded list of detailed instructions.¬†

Schaefer‚Äôs medicine how-to prompts include, ‚ÄúCan‚Äôt poop? Take 2 SennaLax before bed,‚Äù and ‚ÄúOops, condom broke? Take 1 Plan B ASAP after unprotected sex (within 72 hours).‚Äù

She‚Äôs not being overprotective; she‚Äôs simply passing the torch.¬†

‚ÄúI‚Äôm the Swiss Army knife mom,‚Äù said Schaefer. ‚ÄúI want her to be the Swiss Army knife roommate.‚Äù

Jamie Green wants her Sophia to gain a similar reputation around the dorms.

‚ÄúIt super important to be prepared,‚Äù Jamie, a social worker who‚Äôs also at Boise State pursuing a master‚Äôs degree, told The Post.

She hopes Sophia‚Äôs new crop of college friends feels comfortable turning to her for support when necessary.¬†

‚ÄúThe Narcan and Plan B aren‚Äôt necessarily for Sophia, but they‚Äôre for anyone on campus in need,‚Äù said Jamie. ‚ÄúThey can confidentially come to her and get help.‚Äù

Sophia, an aspiring OB/GYN, looks forward to being a safe haven over the next four years.¬†

‚ÄúMy mom and I have always had a very open relationship, and it feels really great that she‚Äôs setting me up for success in case of any emergencies because s‚Äìt happens,‚Äù said Sophia. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs better to be prepared than keeping secrets, lying and maybe ending up in a worse situation.¬†

‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad other girls in my dorm will be able to trust me or my mom if they don‚Äôt have anyone else.‚Äù¬†

Two moped riders were killed on the Bronx River Parkway early Monday when a Mercedes driver slammed into them, police and law enforcement sources said.

The 2019 Mercedes C class sedan was traveling south in the left lane when it moved to the center lane and rear-ended a Volkswagen GTI, causing it to careen into a guardrail near East Gun Hill Road in the Bronx around 12:30 a.m., authorities said.

The Mercedes then plowed into two men, ages 21 and 23, who were thrown from their¬†Fly Wing scooters, authorities said.

The 21-year-old rider was rushed to Jacobi Medical Center, where he was pronounced dead, and the 23-year-old victim succumbed to his injuries at Montefiore Hospital, the NYPD said.

The Mercedes driver was taken into custody, but no charges have been filed, sources said.

The fatal crash led to closures of part of the parkway for a few hours.

The names of the two moped riders haven‚Äôt been released pending family notification.¬†

A proposed casino in Coney Island will bring year-round ‚Äútraffic hell‚Äù to Brooklyn‚Äôs beachy neighborhood, according to one of the six members of the state community advisory council who will vote on whether to approve it.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not just going to be the summer of hell. It will be traffic hell all year round, and garbage hell, noise hell, crime hell,‚Äù Marissa Solomon, an appointee of Assemblyman Alec Brook-Krasny, told The Post.

The bid will be rejected if it is not approved by four of the six CAC members next month.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to replace a piece of American history to build another casino? It makes no sense for the people who live here,‚Äù said Solomon, a Coney Island resident.

The glitzy $3 billion Coney casino plan along Surf Avenue from West 12th to West 15th streets includes a 500-room hotel, a convention center and a concert venue.

The project is contingent on securing one of three casino licenses the state plans to award in and around New York City by the end of this year, with the neighborhood CAC the initial review.

The Coney bid is a partnership that includes Thor Equities, Chickasaw Nation‚Äôs Global Gaming Solutions, Saratoga Casino Holdings and Legends Hospitality Group, which is part-owned by the Yankees.

Solomon gave the Coney bidder‚Äôs environment-traffic study plan a withering reception at a July 30 CAC meeting.

She read directly from the bidder‚Äôs traffic report included in the environmental impact statement that cited severe traffic impacts at numerous locations, including 15th Street, Surface Avenue and Stillwell Avenue.

The plan envisions 1,500 on-site parking spots, but admits up to 912 more parking space would be needed off-site ‚Äî even during the off-season

‚ÄúYour own transportation study said there would be significant adverse impacts at multiple intersections‚Ä¶ and your only mitigation is two new lights and some new stripes? Really?‚Äù she asked.

‚ÄúIs that going to be able to handle what your own report says is a complete breakdown in traffic?‚Äù

The bidders seemed to be caught off guard by Solomon‚Äôs critique.

But a rep for the Coney, contacted by The Post, insisted the casino complex will spur use of mass transit and not create endless traffic jams.

‚ÄúThe Coney will make massive once in a lifetime improvements to Coney Island‚Äôs transit accessibility after decades of neglect by adopting and improving the Stillwell Ave subway station, easing traffic flow through rerouting streets, aligning traffic lights, hiring traffic cops and funding infrastructure investments like a new ferry,‚Äù said Coney‚Äôs Robert Cornegy, the former Brooklyn councilman.

‚ÄúIn addition, we‚Äôre also going to offer discounted or complimentary round-trip subway fares for guests and employees and partner with the MTA to provide express subway service directly from Manhattan to Coney Island ‚Äî all things that will help get people out of cars while also helping improve Coney Island.‚Äù

It‚Äôs an open question whether higher-roller gamblers would take the subway rather than drive to a casino, gaming insiders said.

The Coney bid is really rolling the dice given the strong community opposition, including from Luna Park Amusement and Community Board 13.

‚ÄúCasinos are not engines of sustainable development‚Äîthey are predatory institutions that exploit financial vulnerability, depress surrounding businesses, and increase social burdens such as crime, addiction, and poverty. Coney Island deserves investment in education, healthcare, and small business support‚Äînot a casino that siphons wealth from the community under the guise of economic development,‚Äù an anti-casino petition promoted on the Luna Park website says.

‚ÄúThe future of Coney Island should be shaped by its residents, not dictated by corporate developers behind closed doors.‚Äù

The six members on the CAC include reps for Gov. Kathy Hochul and Mayor Eric Adams, Brooklyn Borough President Antonio Reynoso, state Sen. Jessica Scarcella-Spanton and Councilman Justin Brannan.

If it is approved by the CAC, the Coney bid would then be evaluated by the New York Gaming Facility Location Board, which will recommend up to three casino licenses.

The state Gaming Commission will then make the final decision on licensing for bidders who make the final cut.

Over 3,500 homeless New Yorkers have been taken off Big Apple streets and subways and placed in permanent housing since the start of Mayor Eric Adams‚Äô term, Hizzoner announced on Monday ‚Äî touting it as proof that his ‚ÄúSubway Safety Plan‚Äù is working.

Over 1,000 of the housing placements came directly from the subway system since the plan launched in early 2022 as part of a broader effort to curb the ongoing homelessness crisis in transit stations, officials said.

The recent milestone is the centerpiece of Adams‚Äô new ‚ÄúEnd Anything Goes‚Äù campaign ‚Äî a push to show how his administration is cracking down on public disorder while expanding services for New Yorkers with mental illness and addiction, City Hall announced.

The campaign will highlight the current efforts the administration has made to date to ‚Äúchange the culture‚Äù and laws that have prevented mentally ill New Yorkers from seeking help ‚Äî while also making investments to support outreach, harm reduction, and housing, Adams said.

‚ÄúFrom the beginning, we said we needed to build trust with the city‚Äôs unsheltered population, whether outside, on our subways, or in our shelters,‚Äù Adams said in a statement.

‚ÄúThis success would not be possible without our historic investments,‚Äù the mayor said, crediting Safe Haven beds, outreach teams, and a ‚Äúrecord-breaking creation of affordable housing.‚Äù

‚ÄúMore work remains, but it‚Äôs clear that the years of walking by New Yorkers in need are over, and this milestone is further proof that we‚Äôre continuing to make New York City a safer, more affordable city.‚Äù

Since launching the multi-agency Subway Safety Plan, the city has connected 8,600 people to types of shelter, with over 1,000 now in permanent homes. The effort focuses on outreach at stations to pull people with serious mental health issues out of the transit system.

The MTA said this July had the lowest transit-crime stats since 1995 when the data was first collected, with an 8% drop in felonies in the subways last month ‚Äî even as a string of violent crimes in the subway system recently left a straphanger slashed and another shoved onto the tracks by a muttering maniac.

Hizzoner also touted the city‚Äôs growing network of shelter beds, with 400 more Safe Haven beds to house the homeless and transition them to permanent housing to be added by the end of 2025.

So far, 1,600 new beds have been added since Adams took office, City Hall said.

Adams introduced a $650 million plan to tackle homelessness and get mentally ill New Yorkers off the streets and out of subways during his State of the City speech¬†in January ‚Äì begging Albany for more help tackling the Big Apple‚Äôs ongoing crisis.

The¬†ambitious, five-year¬†proposal ‚Äî which is set to include a¬†special new facility to house and treat mentally ill New Yorkers ‚Äî follows a spate of frightening underground attacks that have plagued the transit system of late.

As part of the plan, a $13 million ‚Äúpilot program,‚Äù as described by a City Hall rep, would create a 100-bed supportive housing facility that would provide shelter to people leaving psychiatric facilities who are not yet ready to fully live alone without support to continue their meds and treatment, officials said.

The initiative would also¬†add 900 ‚ÄúSafe Haven‚Äù beds, which will be spread across the city, to house the homeless and transition them to permanent housing ‚Äî bringing the total to 4,900. An additional 100 beds will also be added to serve runaway and homeless youth ages 21-24.

And a new ‚ÄúBridge to Home‚Äù model under the proposal will offer home-like environments to patients with serious mental illnesses at NYC Health + Hospitals.

The program will target patients who are ready to be discharged from hospitals but have nowhere to go home to, officials said.

item.description:
New York City will launch stricter rules for cooling towers after one of the worst Legionnaires‚Äô outbreaks in years broke out in Harlem.

The city Health Department plans on ramping up enforcement, penalties and reporting requirements for building water systems that are considered the source of many cases of Legionnaires‚Äô disease.

There have been three deaths and 81 infections reported in Harlem over the prior two weeks, with 24 people hospitalized.

Health Department officials, when contacted by The Post, insisted the amended rules for cooling towers were in the works before the Harlem outbreak, which they said has been brought under control.

The beefed up rules are scheduled to go into effect next spring.

In a notice posted in The City Record, regulators proposed amending current rules ‚Äúto provide penalties for failure to comply with reporting inspections that include test sampling for Legionella‚Äù and to ‚Äúdefine penalties for requirements previously added‚Äù to the city administrative code.

The revisions will also add a new laboratory certification requirement for Legionella. Any such sampling must be conducted by a laboratory certified by the New York State Environmental Laboratory Accreditation Program.

The goal is to ‚Äúimprove enforcement,‚Äù the Health Department‚Äôs Bureau of Environmental Sciences and Engineering said.

Jory Lange, one lawyer who specializes in Legionnaires‚Äô cases, said New York City already has the toughest rules for cleaning towers in the country ‚Äúbut the building owners are not following them.‚Äù

Lange said the current level of fines are not stiff enough to force compliance in buildings worth tens of millions of dollars.

He said it is troubling that 11 of the 43 towers inspected in Harlem ‚Äî about 25% ‚Äî tested positive for Legionella.

Also, inspections for Legionella bacteria in the city‚Äôs cooling towers plummeted in the months leading up to an outbreak in Harlem, according to a review of records by Gothamist.

The department inspected 5,200 cooling towers and issued over 48,000 violations to building owners in 2017 after a new law went into effect following a deadly Legionnaires‚Äô outbreak in The Bronx.

This year, the city projected completing fewer than half that number of inspections, a record low when excluding the 2020 and 2021 COVID-19 pandemic years, the Gothamist review found.

People can catch Legionnaires‚Äô disease from bacterial droplets that come from water systems like cooling towers.

It can take between 12 and14 days from exposure to the droplets to start feeling sick, according to city Acting Health Commissioner Dr. Michelle Morse.

The current rules for owners of buildings with cooling towers lay out a range of penalties covering 31 different categories.

The maximum fine of $1,000 for a first offense and $2,000 for each additional offense include: failing to take immediate action for positive legionella results; failing to take samples for reporting them to the department;, not properly using recycle or rainwater; failure to minimize the release of water droplets that carry Legionella or having no maintenance program.

Owners also currently face initial $500 fines for failing to routinely monitor and conduct inspections for Legionnaires‚Äô disease or cleaning the tanks, or failing to increase chlorine or other disinfectants during the summer months of July and August when Legionella is more of a threat.

The city declined to provide any more details at this point about the beefed-up enforcement.

The girlfriend of a US tourist shot dead while in Puerto Rico for a Bad Bunny concert is mourning the loss of her fianc√©-to-be in a series of heart-wrenching posts ‚Äî just hours after she shared happy snaps from their night out.

Angy Nicole Arguello, the longtime girlfriend of 25-year-old Kevin Mares, wrote ‚ÄúI love you, my angel‚Äù with a broken heart emoji in an Instagram story alongside a photo of the young couple after Mares‚Äô untimely death in La Perla on Sunday.

‚ÄúMy love, I love you. I miss you so much. Why, God, did you take him away from me?‚Äù she said in a follow-up pic of Mares smiling.

Mares was planning to propose to Arguello in the fall, according to a GoFundMe created to help cover the expenses to bring his body back home to New York City.

The couple, both from Queens, had been together for six years, the fundraiser said.

Just hours before the tragedy hit, Arguello and Mares each posted carefree snapshots of palm trees, resort pools and clinking glasses with pals during their Puerto Rico vacation.

Mares was shot twice while hanging out at a popular nightspot in La Perla, a shantytown on the outskirts of Old San Juan, officials said.

He is believed to have been an innocent bystander when two people nearby started arguing and one pulled out a gun.

He was shot in the abdomen and side,¬†according to NBC 6 South Florida, and was rushed to a hospital but died.

At least two others, both La Perla locals, were shot and remain hospitalized.

Mares was in Puerto Rico with his girlfriend and a friend to see the popular local rapper perform in a 30-show residency that‚Äôs drawn thousands of US tourists to the Caribbean island and US territory.

Loved ones described the 25-year-old as ‚Äúa deeply loved son, devoted friend, and a source of inspiration to everyone who knew him‚Äù in a GoFundMe page created to help cover the expenses to bring his body back home.

‚ÄúHis wholehearted kindness, adventurous spirit, and unwavering commitment to family made him a pillar of strength for his loved ones,‚Äù the fundraising page read, adding that Mares was planning to propose to his girlfriend of six years in the fall.

‚ÄúFamily was at the center of everything he did, and his sudden passing has left an unfillable void in our lives,‚Äù loved ones wrote on the page.

The shooter remains at large, local police told NBC 6.

‚ÄúWe have very little information,‚Äù said San Juan detective Sgt. Arnaldo Ruiz.

La Perla has been dogged by a reputation for crime and violence for decades.

item.description:
New York Gov. Kathy Hochul renamed a Central Park subway station after Malcolm X, the prominent civil rights leader who was a longtime Harlem resident, as part of the city‚Äôs Harlem Week celebration.

The legislation penned by Hochul will rename the 110 St-Central Park North subway station to 110 St-Malcolm X Plaza in honor of the slain revolutionary, who lived sporadically in the neighborhood between his late teens and the final decade of his life.

This year‚Äôs celebration also marked the 100th anniversary of the Harlem Renaissance, the era following the Great Migration where 175,000 black residents moved to the neighborhood to escape the rampant racism and Jim Crow legislation plaguing the South.

‚ÄúOne of the best ways to celebrate the rich history and community of Harlem is to recognize the contributions of Malcolm X and the Harlem Renaissance to New York and to the world,‚Äù Hochul said.

‚ÄúFrom the struggle for civil rights and equality to boundary-breaking cultural impacts of American icons like Zora Neale Hurston and Duke Ellington, Harlem has been at the center of progress in our nation for generations.‚Äù

Malcolm X, a contested Black Nationalist leader up through his assassination in 1965, sought to strike a balance with Martin Luther King Jr.‚Äôs early pacifist approach and the raw violence people of color faced in America.

Early in his civil rights advocacy, Malcolm X, originally born Malcolm Little before abandoning his ‚Äúslave name,‚Äù was a devout follower of Elijah Muhammad, a black separatist and second leader of the Nation of Islam, according to the African American Intellectual History Society.

Malcolm X‚Äôs faith shaped much of his work, including his insistence on racial separation and his criticism of King‚Äôs nonviolent approach.

But in 1964, Malcolm X suddenly denounced separatism after a fateful pilgrimage to Mecca and falling out with Muhammad, citing a ‚Äúspiritual rebirth,‚Äù as reported by the New York Times at the time.

King and Malcolm X were often perceived as having butted heads because of their opposing approaches, with Malcolm X largely lobbing most of the critiques during his public appearances.

The legends only met once while watching early Senate discussions of the Civil Rights Bill of 1964, mere months before Malcolm X‚Äôs death.

Malcolm X‚Äôs stances were always malleable, even more so after his pilgrimage, and at the duo‚Äôs single meeting, he apparently told King that he would be throwing himself ‚Äúinto the heart of the civil rights struggle,‚Äù according to PBS.

‚ÄúPeople always talk about this big transformation. But when you look at him, he continually evolved. He continued to research, to learn, and to adopt his new knowledge in his work,‚Äù Malcolm X‚Äôs daughter, Ilyasah Shabazz, told the Harvard Law Record in 2011.

While Malcolm X was starting to solidify his reshaped approach, he was gunned down by two members of the Nation of Islam while he hosted a meeting for the Organization of Afro-American Unity in Manhattan.

Other parts of Harlem already bear his name, including the Malcolm Shabazz Harlem Market and the Malcolm Shabazz Plaza.

The election race to lead the most populous town in the US has gone down a perverted rabbit hole featuring bestiality, porn and a Marine veteran ex-NYPD cop.

The campaign for Long Island‚Äôs Town of Hempstead supervisor turned sickeningly X-rated when an old social-media post recently surfaced suggesting Democratic candidate Joseph Scianablo once boasted about looking at ‚Äúanimal porn.‚Äù

‚Äúi just s‚Äît myself while watchinG animal porn,‚Äù reads the Dec. 27, 2008, post on Scianablo‚Äôs Facebook page.

While Scianablo is claiming his brother posed as him to post the twisted missive as a joke, the Dem‚Äôs foe, interim Republican Hempstead Supervisor John Ferretti, said he is still disgusted by the antics involving ‚Äúbestiality‚Äù and that the whole sordid ordeal makes his opponent unfit for office.

‚ÄúThis is not a joke. This is not a youthful mistake. This is a statement that celebrates the
abuse and exploitation of animals‚Äîand it is beneath the dignity of any individual
seeking public office,‚Äù Ferretti told The Post.

Ferretti noted that the job of Hempstead Town supervisor involves the direct oversight of the Hempstead Animal Shelter, which is designed to rescue, protect and care for cats and dogs, many of which have already been victims of cruelty and neglect.

‚ÄúThe idea that someone who created a social media post to celebrate bestiality and publicly joked about it could be in charge of protecting animals is both sickening and unacceptable,‚Äù Ferretti said. ‚ÄúWe are not talking about politics‚Äîwe‚Äôre talking about basic decency, judgment, and humanity.‚Äù

Scianablo ‚Äî a Marine combat veteran, retired NYPD officer and former prosecutor in the Queens District Attorney‚Äôs Office ‚Äî admitted that the post was written under his name but claimed he was the victim of a prank by his brother, Jason, at the time.

‚ÄúI have a dopey brother who did this,‚Äù Scianablo told The Post on Sunday.

‚ÄúMy brother took my computer and posted it [the animal porn],‚Äù added the candidate, who was 31 at the time of the posting.

‚ÄúThis is nothing but a smear,‚Äù Scianablo said. ‚ÄúMy record speaks for itself.‚Äù

His campaign, in full damage-control mode, then provided a statement it says is from Jason fessing up to the prank.

‚ÄúIn 2008, I made a stupid, juvenile post on my brother‚Äôs Facebook as a joke,‚Äù said the campaign statement attributed to Jason. ‚ÄúMy brother had returned from serving in combat as a US Marine in Iraq. Ferretti has meanwhile promoted his animal-rights record as a Nassau County legislator. He authored legislation that bans convicted animal abusers from owning pets and increased penalties for leaving animals in hot or freezing cars, while also cracking down on animal hoarders.

‚ÄúThis election is about who we can trust to do what‚Äôs right. And clearly, Joe Scianablo is not that person,‚Äù Ferretti said.

The race was already mired in controversy.

Ferretti replaced Don Clavin, the three-term GOP town supervisor who stepped down before his term expired at year‚Äôs end.

Scianablo and other Democrats cried foul, saying it was a GOP power play to give Ferretti a leg up with the power of incumbency in the general election this fall.

A ritzy Upper East Side private school has won its fight to turn a public street into its own private playground for the academic year ‚Äî prompting businesses on the block to cry foul.

Gov. Kathy Hochul slighted mayoral hopeful Zohran Mamdani in a live TV interview Sunday ‚Äî signaling she may not endorse him in the election even after he praised her ‚Äúcourage.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe still have many differences,‚Äù Hochul said, keeping her distance from her fellow Democrat during a Fox News Sunday interview. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know how you whitewash that away.‚Äù

Fox host Shannon Bream had read a statement from Mamdani effusively praising Hochul for sparring with President Trump and Republicans over redistricting fights that could dictate who controls Congress.

Mamdani said Hochul showed ‚Äúcourage‚Äù and was ‚Äúmeeting the moment.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs the feeling mutual? Is Mamdani a good choice‚Äù [for New York City mayor], Bream asked, sparking Hochul to bring up their ‚Äúmany differences.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe can agree with me and many people agree with me and I think it‚Äôs not just Democrats who say, ‚ÄòNew Yorkers stand up for our rights.‚Äô We do that,‚Äù Hochul said.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre fighters. I‚Äôm a mom from Buffalo. I guess they‚Äôre not used to taking on a mom from Buffalo.‚Äù

Hochul, who is seeking re-election next year, has come out against Mamdani‚Äôs proposals to hike taxes by $9 billion on millionaires and corporations in the city to fund his affordability agenda of subsidized child care, fare-free bus services, housing expansion and government-run grocery stores.

Those taxes need sign off from the governor and state lawmakers, who also are up for re-election in 2026.

Despite the apparent snub, Hochul did say she agrees with Mamdani‚Äôs focus on tackling New York‚Äôs high cost of living and making both the city and state more affordable for residents.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs many areas of disagreement,‚Äù she noted. ‚ÄúBut also there‚Äôs areas of alignment including affordability. His election touched a nerve. And people said, ‚Äòyou know what, we‚Äôre just not getting ahead.'‚Äù

She claimed that President Trump‚Äôs policies, including imposing tariffs, have not helped.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a sense that we need some change now,‚Äù Hochul said.

Hochul then hinted she may sit out the race and not endorse Mamdani, who is running against two other Democrats running on independent party lines ‚Äî Mayor Eric Adams and ex-Gov. Andrew Cuomo, whom she served with as lieutenant governor. She took over as governor when Cuomo resigned as governor amid sexual misconduct accusations that he denies.

‚ÄúI already worked with two different mayors. I‚Äôll continue to work with whomever the voters want me to and I‚Äôll make it work out. I‚Äôm not going to go to war with the 8 million residents of New York I also represent,‚Äù the governor said.

MTA officials touted a ‚Äúhistoric‚Äù dip in Big Apple subway crime in a glowing announcement Sunday ‚Äî just hours after a straphanger was slashed and another shoved onto the tracks by a muttering maniac.

The transit agency said July produced the lowest transit-crime stats since the data was first collected in 1995, with an 8% drop in felonies in the subways last month ‚Äî including a 16.7% plummet in robberies and a 9.3% decrease in felony assaults compared to the same month last year.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs clear the efforts to increase overnight patrols, deploy thousands more security cameras and expand mental health outreach are having real positive impacts,‚Äù MTA Chair and CEO Janno Lieber said in a statement.

‚ÄúBy working closely with Gov. [Kathy] Hochul and the NYPD, we‚Äôre making sure the transit system not only is safe, but feels safe for our six million daily riders,‚Äù Lieber said.

But try telling that to some of this month‚Äôs victims ‚Äî including an ER pediatrician at Harlem Hospital who just feels ‚Äúhappy he‚Äôs still alive‚Äù after his brush with death on the rails over the weekend.

The 44-year-old doctor was heading home from work and waiting for a No. 1 train in Manhattan around 8 p.m. Saturday ‚Äî a few hours before the MTA‚Äôs crowing press release ‚Äî when a screaming vagrant randomly shoved him onto the tracks.

The banged-up doc was able to scramble back up onto the platform with help from other straphangers before a train was set to barrel into the station fewer than 4 minutes later. His assailant fled the station and remains on the loose.

About an hour after that attack, another subway rider was slashed in the neck and armpit after getting into a spat with a knife-wielding nut at an East Village station.

That attacker also fled the station and remains on the loose, while his victim was taken to Bellevue Hospital and treated for his injuries, according to police.

The back-to-back transit assaults came after another attack Wednesday, when a masked thug slashed a 29-year-old woman multiple times after she refused to surrender her bag at the Wall Street station.

The crook demanded the woman‚Äôs bag aboard a northbound No. 3 train around 11:10 p.m. when he attacked her, according to police and law enforcement sources.

Still, according to MTA statistics, subway crimes are not only down month-over-month from last year, but also year-to-date, ‚Äúled by a drop in overall assaults, even as more riders return to the system,‚Äù the transit agency‚Äôs chief security officer, Michael Kemper, said in the statement.

When The Post reached out to the MTA for comment over the timing of its press release Sunday, its public-information department said to contact the NYPD‚Äôs press office.

This one‚Äôs foul territory.

‚ÄúEntitled‚Äù pet owners have taken over a popular Brooklyn ballfield ‚Äî forcing some Little League teams to flee the site amid the leftover slippery dog waste and dangerous holes dug by off-leash pooches.

The 3-acre Green Central Knoll park, which sits on the border of trendy Bushwick and Williamsburg, has been attracting dozens of dog owners for the past few years because of the massive size of its athletic field, locals told The Post.

The canines‚Äô owners have been dogged in their illicit use of the space ‚Äî despite posted ‚Äúno pets‚Äù signs and fines frequently issued to them by city Parks Department officers.

While the sports field was supposed to be locked up when it hadn‚Äôt been in use by permitted leagues, the pet owners ‚Äúabused the fields for off-leash dog play, and waste was being left behind‚Äù during a brief period when fences were left open during construction, a Parks rep said.

Hoards of pet owners ‚Äî some hailing from the area‚Äôs new luxury developments with private dog runs ‚Äî took that as a signal of fair game and now descend on the field daily to use as an unauthorized dog run by climbing through a fence that is ripped and still open.

‚ÄúWe still hear from our park manager on a somewhat regular basis that they literally have to replace locks and fences that get cut because there are folks that feel entitled to use that space for their dogs, even though it‚Äôs abundantly clear that that is not what that space is for,‚Äù said Bushwick Community Board 4 District Manager Celeste Leon to The Post.

Other locals have raised concerns about the off-leash pets posing a threat after two children, including a young baseball player, were bitten this spring at nearby parks.

The community-board manager noted complaints of pet owners harassing Parks staff, too, as well as reports of ringworm and kids slipping in waste and twisting ankles from holes.

‚ÄúThe dogs dig really big holes in the floor,‚Äù a young ball player said, noting he‚Äôs come ‚Äúclose‚Äù to injury, too, multiple times.

Pooches must be leashed at city parks unless during specified off-leash hours, according to the city‚Äôs website.

At the dog-free athletic field, the scores of loose pooches could result in owner fines of up to $150 a pop ‚Äì but for some pet owners, it‚Äôs a small price to pay for coveted green space.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs nowhere for them to go without walking half an hour,‚Äù argued a 34-year-old dog owner who only gave her first name, Rachel.

She was fined for $150 in February ‚Äì and continues to frequent the park.

‚ÄúYou come here because there‚Äôs no other place to go,‚Äù she said.

The closest dog run in the neighborhood is a 20-minute walk to Maria Hernandez Park, which The Post previously reported has been riddled with issues such as flooding, scattered rat poison and dangerous barbed grass.

‚ÄúIt sucks,‚Äù said 33-year-old resident Ben Lee, who has been fined $100 from Parks, of the Hernandez Park run. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs gravel, a lot of people bring dogs that are not super friendly.

‚ÄúThis is the only patch of grass in the area,‚Äù Lee said of the ballfield.

A 38-year-old resident named Alex said, ‚ÄúThe dog parks are pretty underwhelming at most places, and they‚Äôre very small.

‚ÄúIt can be a stressful space for them or a dangerous place.

‚ÄúMany of the dog owners, during what would be off-leash hours in Prospect Park and Central Park, [treat] before 9 a.m. as off-leash,‚Äù Alex said. ‚ÄúSo we kind of stick to that ‚Äî or try to, at least.‚Äù¬†

Pointing to the incident of a child bit by a pit bull at Thomas Boyland Park, he said, ‚ÄúPeople that come here are usually very responsible.

‚ÄúThose aren‚Äôt the type of people that come here.‚Äù

Dog owner Jasmine Hinds insisted, ‚ÄúThe bigger dogs, they like to catch the balls, but they‚Äôre not violent.‚Äù

A rep for City Councilwoman Jen Gutierrez said local officials are now in ‚Äúactive‚Äù talks with Parks about either creating a dedicated dog run within Green Central Knoll or ‚Äústrengthening the turf to better withstand use.‚Äù¬†

item.description:
Like millions of other Post readers, for most of my life, I knew my uncle Pete Hamill ‚Äì the legendary columnist and novelist who died five years ago this week age 85 ‚Äì through his writing.

I devoured his books, pored over his columns, and annotated his magazine articles like there was going to be a quiz.

It‚Äôs a tall order to get a large Irish-Catholic family all in one room, and ‚Äì outside of a handful of family reunions ‚Äì I didn‚Äôt see him much.

Until, that was, the summer of 2018, when we were having lunch in Park Slope at my great-grandfather‚Äôs old bar of choice, Rattigan‚Äôs, for the first get-together in a decade.

The former watering hole is now a Mexican restaurant ‚Äì like everything in the city ‚Äì and had been Pete‚Äôs favorite since his days studying art at Mexico City College.

It was across from the top floor, tenement railroad flat where Pete ‚Äì the eldest of seven Hamill kids ‚Äì was raised.

I was nervous walking in.

Since deciding to pursue a writing career like my uncle, I was determined to make a good impression. But the moment we started talking, my sweaty jitters evaporated in the August heat.

There are few people in life with whom you click from the word go. Pete was one of them.

We talked about everything from philosopher Albert Camus‚Äô sense of humor, to free trade, to our love for Walt Whitman‚Äôs ‚ÄúLeaves of Grass,‚Äù and our shared admiration for Philip Roth and Mark Twain.¬†

We even found time to eat. Taking his first bite of his burrito, Pete looked heavenwards and cried, ‚ÄúMaybe there is a God after all!‚Äù

After the reunion, he hired me as a research assistant for what would have been his final book.

Pete taught me something new every day that year ‚Äì from practical writing tips on using concrete nouns and active verbs, to advice on the craft.

He told me how stories aren‚Äôt measured in inches on the page but by the tread on your shoes, and how, even if your mother tells you she loves you, double-check it.

But I also learned so much more.

I learned how fervently he loved his wife, Fukiko, and how much she loved him back.¬†

He taught me that the 20th century‚Äôs three worst people were Hitler, Stalin, and former Brooklyn Dodgers owner Walter O‚ÄôMalley, who hijacked the team to LA in 1957.

And not necessarily in that order.

Even though Pete was in his 80s and on dialysis, he still found the energy to belt out songs in Spanish randomly.

I learned I was just one of dozens of young writers he took under his wing over the years, and that he offered me the job before recognizing me, thinking I was my cousin‚Äôs friend.

Pete never forgot his roots as a poor Brooklyn kid, offering his time and attention to almost anyone who asked. He was a most generous man.

Out of his many legacies, that‚Äôs the one I cherish the most.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt miss me when I‚Äôm gone,‚Äù Pete would often say. ‚ÄúI had the best life a kid from Brooklyn could have dreamt of.‚Äù

Sometimes, like this week, I selfishly do.

I don‚Äôt know if there is a God up there after all. If there is, I hope St. Peter opens the gates wide enough for papers to get delivered.

If not, that‚Äôs fine too.

Because while I may not find you in the grass under my boot-soles, I can spot you in the cracks in the sidewalk. I can hear your gravely voice singing through the whizz of a passing subway car.¬† And I hear your laugh when thumbing through the headlines in The Post.

The straphanger randomly shoved onto tracks by a muttering maniac Saturday is an ER pediatrician who was on his way home from work at the time ‚Äî and is now just ‚Äúhappy he‚Äôs still alive,‚Äù his pal told The Post.

The 44-year-old victim was heading back to his Upper West Side pad after a shift at Harlem Hospital and waiting for a No. 1 train at the 50th Street and Seventh Avenue station in Manhattan around 7:50 p.m. when the nut came up behind him, according to cops and the friend, Takayuki Matsumoto.

‚Äú[The unhinged attacker] was screaming and walking toward him, and the next thing, [the victim] was pushed,‚Äù said Matsumoto, speaking to The Post at the home of the injured rider, who was inside sleeping while recovering, on Sunday.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not like he was walking on the edge of the platform or anything,‚Äù the man said of his doctor friend. ‚ÄúHe was walking in the middle of it, and suddenly, this guy approached him and pushed him.

‚ÄúHis staff at the hospital said, ‚ÄòDon‚Äôt take the train anymore,‚Äô ‚Äù Matsumoto added of his pal.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs lucky he‚Äôs OK. He‚Äôs happy that he‚Äôs still alive.‚Äù

Matsumoto, 62, said the victim was aware at the time that there was a train coming into the station in under 4 minutes, so he scrambled back onto the platform quickly with help from ‚Äúa nice couple and a lady.‚Äù

The doctor, whose name is being withheld by The Post, suffered bruises to his face and leg.

Cops are currently searching for the suspect, who was described as around 6 feet tall and wearing a white shirt, black shorts and a black backpack.

The attack was one of a slew of recent violent incidents on the rails.

Police also are looking for the man who stabbed another subway rider in the neck during a dispute at an East Village subway station Saturday night.

In addition, a masked stranger slashed a 29-year-old woman on a Lower Manhattan train late Wednesday when she refused to hand him her bag ‚Äî and he is still in the wind, too.

The violence did not stop clueless MTA officials crowing Sunday that July marked the lowest subway violence month since 1995.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the only way he can get to the hospital,‚Äù the friend said.

‚ÄúICE law enforcement, along with our partners, are doing what ‚ÄúSanctuary‚Äù politicians refuse to do ‚Äî protect the American people,‚Äù the agency said, denouncing the liberal policy of refusing to allow cops to coordinate with immigration agents.

The agency cited a list of who it considers the worst of the worst that it has picked up in both counties since the start of the year, including the notorious gang members, killers and sought global suspects.

But ICE would not say how many of the 1,600 people rounded up had serious versus low-level prior offenses or how many others without criminal records have also been taken into custody ‚Äî a category that includes a Port Washington bagel shop manager and a Suffolk County Community College student in recent months.

‚ÄúICE is going after criminals first,‚Äù Blakeman said Thursday. ‚ÄúYes, when they go after criminals, there could be other people who are caught up. But what I do know is, they‚Äôre not raiding schools, and they‚Äôre not raiding churches.‚Äù¬†

Nassau County Legislator Seth Koslow, a Democrat running against Blakeman for county executive in November, has called for the incumbent to limit cooperation with ICE to cases involving violent crimes and not to use county resources to target immigrants without serious convictions.

If elected, Koslow would apparently likely end Nassau‚Äôs current partnership with the agency.

‚ÄúI believe Nassau County‚Äôs resources should only be used to assist ICE in removing violent criminals who threaten our neighborhoods, not to go after hardworking, taxpaying residents who are contributing to our community,‚Äù Koslow said.

Suffolk officials, on the other hand, have recently distanced themselves from cooperating with ICE in part because of a $60 million court ruling earlier this year tied to the sheriff department‚Äôs past work with the agency.

Still, federal agents continue to find a foothold in the county. In Islip, a taxpayer-funded gun range is being used to train ICE agents under a quiet Department of Homeland Security deal, and in Brentwood, a local firehouse parking lot was taken over by ICE as a makeshift base of operations.¬†

ICE also is still getting help from both counties through what‚Äôs known as immigration ‚Äúdetainers‚Äù ‚Äî a request for local officials to tip the agency off when specific people in custody are about to be released.¬†

Sheriffs in Nassau and Suffolk both said they give ICE advanced notice, letting agents wait outside the jail to make an arrest the moment someone they‚Äôre targeting walks out.

Between January and June, ICE issued 635 detainers on Long Island ‚Äî 341 in Nassau and 294 in Suffolk ‚Äî mostly for men from Central and South America in their late 30s who, according to UC Berkeley‚Äôs Deportation Data Project, weren‚Äôt charged with serious crimes.¬†

Detainers don‚Äôt require review by a court or judge, and local law enforcement isn‚Äôt legally obligated to respond.

ICE did not confirm the research group‚Äôs numbers.

A Queens homeowner illegally turned his house into an Airbnb-style hotel with numbered units and even a soda machine ‚Äì but refused to pay $420,000 in fines when he was caught, a new lawsuit claims.

Gurcharan Kaur has yet to fork over the cash from seven separate $60,000 fines issued in fall 2022, when he was accused of converting his Kew Gardens home into a getaway with daily bookings, the suit alleges.¬†

Kaur was found in violation by an administrative court, but yet to pay a dime of the nearly half-a-million dollars in fines ‚Äî and the time to challenge the violations has passed, the city said.

Kaur‚Äôs son denied the violations at a 2023 administrative hearing, but ‚Äúoffered no rebuttal evidence or testimony to the violating conditions established by the DOB,‚Äù the suit claims.¬†

‚ÄúWe will always use every tool in our toolbox to address illegal and dangerous short-term rentals, including using the levers of the law to ensure that fines imposed are collected and paid ‚Äî instead of ignored,‚Äù said a spokesperson from the Mayor‚Äôs Office of Special Enforcement.¬†

A man at the residence who said he is Kuar‚Äôs son blamed the buildings department for blocking their efforts to rent the building.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been trying to get an inspection done since last year ‚Äî October ‚Äî and there‚Äôs been no response,‚Äù the man told a reporter last week.

The supposed son, who says he works as a contractor, did not comment on the illegal rental allegations, but claimed the city would ultimately ‚Äúwrite off the fines they have.‚Äù

City officials said they could not find a record of the homeowner asking for a re-inspection to clear the vacate order in the three years it has been in place.

In early 2022, the city passed Local Law 18, which largely banned short-term rentals offered by sites like Airbnb, where Kaur posted the rooms under the name Nick, according to images of the listing provided by city officials.¬†

The home ‚Äì which is a single-family home according to city tax records ‚Äì was maintaining seven furnished rooms with key locks and door numbers, according to DOB documents.¬†

A city inspector went to check out the home on 121st Street in October 2022 after a neighbor voiced concerns that Kaur was ‚Äúrenting their house as a [sic] airbnb/hotel for more than a month,‚Äù adding ‚Äúdifferent people are staying everyday‚Äù at the two-story house, according to the initial complaint.

The inspector found empty bedrooms with neatly folded sheets, ‚ÄúNo Smoking‚Äù signs, labeled room keys ‚Äî and a stocked vending machine ‚Äî according to an administrative court hearing in 2023 and documents shared with The Post.

As the inspector went room to room, he found four of the rooms had so-called ‚Äúrenters‚Äù inside, the documents showed.

One of the illegal tenants was allegedly a minor, and had the inspector talk to his mother on the phone, who confirmed that the rental was through Airbnb.

Occupants of two separate rooms in the attic also said they were renting through AirBnB, according to the documents.

Another allegedly said they had been staying at the 121st Street house for ‚Äúone month to take care of his ailing grandmother.‚Äù¬†

The owner testified that the home ‚Äî purchased two years earlier ‚Äî was used as a ‚Äúguest house‚Äù and only family stayed there.

The inspector noted that none of the tenants appeared to be related ‚Äî with one explicitly denying any familial connection.

Kaur added that the soda machine was ‚Äújust for show,‚Äù according to the hearing notes.

But the court officer was not convinced, writing that he ‚Äúdid not provide a valid defense to the charge.‚Äù

The department issued a full vacate order during the inspection ‚Äî plus the $420,000 in fines ‚Äî which is still in place to this day, officials said.¬†

A neighbor who lived next door to the house said that while the neighbors were not noisy, they were ‚Äúannoying‚Äù and would often block her driveway.

While she claimed to a reporter that she had recently seen people inside the house ‚Äî despite the active vacate order ‚Äî a buildings department inspector who visited the home on Friday could not confirm if the building was illegally re-occupied.¬†

Earlier this year, the buildings department approved a permit for Kaur to legally convert the house to a two-family residence ‚Äî which would also correct the violations, the permit claims.

A city official said that since the home is fewer than three units, the nearly half-a-million dollars in fines did not need to be paid prior to the permit‚Äôs approval, but stressed that the fines will still have to be paid ‚Äî even if the building is brought into compliance.

Mayoral candidate Andrew Cuomo proposed ‚ÄúZohran‚Äôs law‚Äù that would block privileged New Yorkers like his socialist rival Zohran Mamdani from living in rent-stabilized apartments.

Mamdani, 33, who rakes in $142,000 a year as a state assemblyman and whose wealthy family includes his filmmaker mom and professor dad, has been living in a $2,300-a-month, one-bedroom pad in Astoria.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm calling the legislation ‚ÄòZohran‚Äôs Law.‚Äô This is obviously an abuse of the system,‚Äù Cuomo told The Post Sunday.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not supposed to be providing rent-stabilized apartments to the children of millionaires.‚Äù

The qualifications would include a ‚Äúmeans test‚Äù based on the monthly rent and other factors, Cuomo said though he did not share specifics.

The legislation would require approval from the Democratic-run state legislature and Gov. Kathy Hochul.

Cuomo has been on the attack against Mamdani since last Friday over the cushy apartment in high cost Astoria.

‚ÄúSomewhere last night in New York City, a single mother and her children slept at a homeless shelter because you, Assemblyman Zohran Mamdani, are occupying her rent-controlled apartment,‚Äù Cuomo wrote in a viral tweet that racked up more than 28 million views.

‚ÄúI am calling on you to move out immediately and give your affordable housing back to an unhoused family who need it. Leaders must show moral clarity. Time to move out,‚Äù Cuomo added.

Mamdani, the Democratic Party nominee, has proposed to freeze the rent of government-regulated apartments if he wins the general election in November.

Former Gov. Cuomo lost to Mamdani in a June Democratic primary but is running in November on the ‚ÄúFight and Deliver‚Äù independent ballot line.

Incumbent Mayor Eric Adams also is running as an independent after dropping out of the primary as he faced federal corruption charges, which have since been dropped.

Curtis Sliwa, the founder of the Guardian Angels, is the Republican nominee and lawyer Jim Walden will also appear on ballots as an independent.

There was one more running of the Bulls.

St. James-Smithtown Little League returned to Long Island as little heroes and champions in the hearts of townsfolk, who threw the boys a glorious parade Sunday, after they came up one game short of the Little League World Series.

‚ÄúThis is a great way to go out. ‚Ä¶ We put our towns on the map,‚Äù Bulls manager Scott Santelli told The Post. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs such a good note, knowing that the community is still behind us and supports us and loves us.‚Äù

Though the team faltered Friday in a tough 12-1 loss in the Metro regional final against Connecticut‚Äôs Fairfield National in Bristol, Conn., this 2025 roster was St. James-Smithtown‚Äôs first New York state champion.

‚ÄúHopefully this is the first of many,‚Äù Santelli said. ‚ÄúI think we have some really good teams coming up in the pipeline.‚Äù

Riding on fire trucks, the boys toured the heart of Smithtown on Sunday morning to the roars of die-hard fans, starting at a local firehouse at 10:30 a.m. and ending at Town Hall a half-hour later.

The Bulls squad were also given the first ever key to Smithtown to celebrate what they did for the North Shore nabe.

‚ÄúAll of Suffolk County is proud of this team,‚Äù county executive Ed Romaine told The Post of the fans who took a ferry to Connecticut for the title game and the bars filled to the brim for watch parties.

A local Stop & Shop made special Bulls cupcakes, and a Smithtown Philly Pretzel factory made special twists in the shape of their logo, too.

‚ÄúEveryone came together to show their support. ‚Ä¶ We can‚Äôt wait to see what you do next year,‚Äù Romaine said.

Bulls on parade

Meanwhile, the players still were soaking in what Santelli called a ‚Äúonce-in-a-lifetime experience.‚Äù

He and his two boys popped into a sporting goods store near the Bristol field Saturday and immediately got recognized from their few games aired on ESPN.

Pitcher Kevin Moran, who led his team in lights-out meditations throughout the tournament, was recognized at a diner in the Constitution State over the weekend as well.

‚ÄúI think the visibility that this is going to give the town is going to help our Little League prosper and get bigger,‚Äù Santelli said.

For Jeremy Katz, who won the New York state home run derby, this summer made him feel like he was in the big leagues, according to his mom, Jodi.

‚ÄúEverything that everybody‚Äôs been doing just to make them feel special and appreciated and supported has been amazing ‚Äî and the boys noticed that. It puts a smile on their faces,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre making a scrapbook of all the news articles to show Jeremy ‚Ä¶ and he just couldn‚Äôt believe it.‚Äù

Santelli was brought to tears after the loss Friday, devastated that his time with the boys, whom he had coached since they were in early elementary school, would soon come to an end.

He can‚Äôt think of a better farewell than Sunday‚Äôs townwide festivities, plus one final trip to Cooperstown with the boys next week for an end-of-summer tournament with his ‚Äúother family.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can guarantee you no other team has had a going-away party like our team has,‚Äù he said.

Jodi Katz, meanwhile, is forever grateful for how Long Island showed how much these kids matter.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to remember this feeling of warmth and support forever,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt makes us so proud.‚Äù
